1.62.text: What if you could use genetic engineering to stop humanity's most dangerous predator?

7.52.text: The deadliest animal on the planet responsible for the death of billions -

14.84.text: Along with other diseases, it plays host to malaria,

18.16.text: one of the cruelest parasites on earth,

20.22.text: possibly the single biggest killer of humans in history.

23.70.text: In 2015 alone, hundreds of millions were infected.

27.28.text: Almost half a million people died.

30.12.text: A new technology could help us eradicate malaria for ever.

34.14.text: But to do so, we need to engineer a whole animal population.

37.80.text: This is not a hypothetical problem,

40.04.text: The modified mosquitoes already exist in a lab.

43.76.text: Should we use the technology, and is malaria bad enough to risk it?

58.68.text: Malaria is caused by a group of micro-organisms.

62.68.text: Very weird micro-organisms, that consist of just a single cell.

67.28.text: They're parasites that completely rely on mosquitoes.

70.88.text: Malaria always starts with an insect bite.

73.62.text: In its salivary glands, thousands of sporozoites wait until the insect penetrates your skin.

79.76.text: Immediately after invading you, they head for the liver,

82.48.text: where they quietly enter big cells and hide from the immune system.

86.72.text: For up to a month, they stay here, in stealth mode, consuming the cells alive and changing into their next form -

96.00.text: They multiply, generating thousands of themselves,

98.80.text: and then burst out of the cells.

101.70.text: So thousands of parasites head into the bloodstream to look for their next victims -

106.88.text: To stay unnoticed, they wrap themselves in the membranes of the cells they killed.

114.66.text: and then taking their skin as camouflage.

118.36.text: They now violently attack red blood cells,

121.44.text: Multiplying inside them until they burst, then finding more red blood cells.

125.70.text: This cycle repeats over and over

128.34.text: Pieces of dead cells spread lots of toxic waste material,

131.34.text: which activates a  powerful immune response causing flu-like symptoms.

135.30.text: Among the symptoms are high fever, sweats and chills,

138.90.text: convulsions, headaches and sometimes vomiting and diarrhea.

142.20.text: If malaria reaches the blood-brain barrier, it can cause coma, neurological damage, or death.

149.62.text: The parasites are ready for evacuation now.

152.28.text: When another mosquito bites the infected human, they get a ride.

163.14.text: spread rapidly into new areas around the globe.

166.10.text: It too is carried by a mosquito.

168.88.text: The mosquito is the perfect carrier for human diseases ,

171.96.text: They've been around for at least 200 million years,

176.06.text: and a single one can lay up to 300 eggs at a time.

180.54.text: They are practically impossible to eradicate,

185.42.text: But today, we have new revolutionary technology

188.18.text: that could enable us to finally win the war against them.

192.28.text: For the first time in human history,

194.48.text: we have the tools to make fast, large-scale changes to entire species,

199.70.text: changing their genetic information as we please.

203.14.text: So, instead of attacking isolated groups of insects,

206.72.text: why not just change the types that transmit diseases?

212.28.text: Scientists successfully created a strain of mosquitos that are immune to the malaria parasite,

217.66.text: by adding a new antibody gene that specifically targets plasmodium.

222.30.text: These mosquitoes will never spread malaria.

225.92.text: But  just changing genetic information is not enough.

229.64.text: The edits would only be inherited by half the offspring,

232.50.text: because most genes have two versions inside the genome as a fail- safe.

236.64.text: So after just two generations, at most only half of the offspring would carry the engineered gene.

241.92.text: In a population of billions of mosquitoes,

244.12.text: They would hardly make a difference

246.82.text: A genetic engineering method called the gene drive solves this problem.

251.14.text: It  forces the new gene to become dominant in the following generations,

254.48.text: overpowering the old gene almost completely.

257.82.text: Thanks to this twist, 99.5% of all the engineered mosquitoes' offspring will carry the anti-malaria edit.

265.80.text: If we were to release enough engineered mosquitoes into the wild to mate with normal mosquitoes,

270.40.text: The malaria-blocking genes would spread extremely quickly.

274.26.text: As the new gene becomes a permanent feature of the mosquito population,

277.70.text: plasmodium would lose its home base.

280.06.text: Scientists hope that the change would be so fast, they could not adapt to it quickly enough.

288.04.text: If you take into account that almost half a million children are killed by it every year,

291.84.text: about five have died since this video started.

295.02.text: Some scientists argue that we should use the technology sooner, rather than later.

299.92.text: The mosquitoes themselves would probably only profit from this.

303.04.text: They don't have anything to gain  from carrying parasites.

306.84.text: And this might only be the first step - malaria might  just be the beginning.

311.46.text: Different mosquitoes also carry Dengue fever and Zika

320.42.text: We could save millions of lives, and prevent suffering on an unbelievable scale.

325.88.text: So,why haven't we done this yet?

328.82.text: For one, CRISPR editing is barely four years old,

331.72.text: so until very recently, we just couldn't do it as fast and easily.

338.44.text: Never before have humans consciously changed the genetic code of a free-living organism on this scale.

344.70.text: Once we do it, there is no going back.

347.92.text: So it has to be done right,

349.60.text: because there could be unwanted consequences if we set out to edit nature

354.56.text: In the specific case of malaria though,

356.36.text: the risk might be acceptable since the genetic modification doesn't make a big change in the overall genome,

361.70.text: It only changes a very specific part.

364.70.text: The worst case scenario here, is probably that it might not work,

368.22.text: or that the parasite adapts in a negative way.

374.32.text: Technology as powerful as gene drive needs to be handled with a lot of care.

379.76.text: But at some point, we have to ask ourselves,

382.26.text: Is it unethical to not use this technology,

385.22.text: when everyday, one thousand children die?

388.78.text: Humanity has to decide how to act on this  in the next few years.
